column4: I need somebody with some real wireless chops. I've been thru the online tutorials etc... Had an intermediate linux guy over to help. No luck. I've got an RaLink RT2561/RT61. Anyone?
i have an rtsomething or other. i suggest you buy a gun and shoot yours. err. i mean, what exactly are you having problems with?
Won't see the access points. Won't pull a dhcp ip address.
you might want to take the easy road and go the ndiswrapper route, if you haven't given that a shot
I have in fact tried that. Same results.
I actually have another wireless card. A usb linksys. Can't get that one working either. Though that one can see the access points.
is the linksys also a ralink?
Don't think so. I can pop it in and see.
Yeah. Apparently so do Airlink 101 ralinks.
I'd see if there were drivers available on the manufacturer's website - they may be newer. the ones on my CD sucked.
if it's any consolation, and you're willing to upgrade in about a week, 7.10 does seem to handle ralinks better. not great, but better. :
did you try compiling the serialmonkey drivers > rt2x00.serialmonkey.com (.net?)
No. I found them, moved on to ndis. I'm NEW on linux. Compiling and installing those drivers was over my head.
was over mine, as well.
when you went the ndiswrapper route, did you try the older driver [9x/me]  if it was available? 2k/xp drivers failed for me? I wish I could say something USEFUL b/c I know how much it sucks :P
I tried the only driver I had, which did not specify 98/xp/etc...
did you get it from a CD or download from the maker's website?
From the cd that came with the card. Kicking around for a while. If I had to guess, I'd say older, not newer.
I went the whole ndis route before I discovered the rt61 driver was in Feisty. (Like I said, I'm new.) Abandoned it for the native one after that. You think the ndis might actually be a better bet?

not having personal experience with that specific ralink chipset, i can't tell you. Getting my own ralink to work was a nightmare, and I was *this* close to selling it and looking for a 3rd adapter when i updated to the 7.10 beta and found my adapter "worked" out of the box. the native drivers for my chipset are just vile. i'm not sure if yours are better.
Didn't post. Spent hours reading and trying stuff though. I'm starting to lean towards installing the Gutsy beta. :)
That RutilT looks interesting.

all you need to do is open a terminal and "sudo apt-get install build-essential checkinstall"  if you dont have them, or search for them synaptic. download, uncompress, switch to the directory, "sh configure" "make" "sudo checkinstall"  (you can "sudo make install" for the last step, but checkinstall will allow for easier removal of things compiled from source)
